page.title: 09HISTORICAL SITES,GATESHEAD
page.content: The {Wrekendyke,}a major{Roman {road,}linked the{South Shields}supply base to{Wrekenton. }It travelled in a north-Easterly direction for most of it's 8.5 mile length, then turned northwards for geological reasons. The present-day road lies on the top of the Wrekendyke for most of it's length, but has been deliberately deviated in places to allow public viewing of it's standard clay-sandstone structure. {Bowes {Railway}is a 15 mile stretch which links{Mount Moor, Springwell}and Burnopfield Collieries through ingenious gravity-worked inclines and stationary engines.The largest incline, designed by{George {Stephenson,}is 1.25 miles long and acts between Springwell and Jarrow.It is the only standard gauge railway in preservation, and is now a{museum.
